articles.headline: Democrats Oust Longtime Leader of House Panel
articles.snippet: Henry A. Waxman’s victory over John D. Dingell is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Henry A. Waxman’s victory over John D. Dingell is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative Henry A. Waxman wrested the chairmanship of the powerful House Energy and Commerce Committee from Representative John D. Dingell on Thursday in a coup that is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by President-elect Barack Obama.

articles.headline: Judge Declares Five Detainees Held Illegally
articles.snippet: A federal judge ordered the release of five Algerian men held at Guantánamo Bay for nearly seven years.
articles.abstract: A federal judge ordered the release of five Algerian men held at Guantánamo Bay for nearly seven years.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge issued the Bush administration a sharp setback on Thursday, ruling that five Algerian men have been held unlawfully at the Guantánamo Bay detention camp for nearly seven years and ordering their release.

articles.headline: Detroit’s Bid for Aid Fails — For Now
articles.snippet: Democratic leaders in Congress gave auto industry leaders 12 days to come back with a plan showing that federal aid would be well-spent.
articles.abstract: Democratic leaders in Congress gave auto industry leaders 12 days to come back with a plan showing that federal aid would be well-spent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Democratic Congressional leaders on Thursday said that the executives of America’s foundering automakers had failed miserably in persuading Congress or the public that $25 billion in aid from the government would be well spent and they gave industry leaders 12 days to come back with plans showing otherwise.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Seeks to Marshal the Piety of the Young
articles.snippet: Hezbollah is educating a younger generation in Lebanon to continue its struggle against Israel.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah is educating a younger generation in Lebanon to continue its struggle against Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYAQ, Lebanon — On a Bekaa Valley playing field gilded by late-afternoon sun, hundreds of young men wearing Boy Scout-style uniforms and kerchiefs stand rigidly at attention as a military band plays, its marchers bearing aloft the distinctive yellow banner of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite movement.

articles.headline: DVDs, Hollywood’s Profit Source, Are Sagging
articles.snippet: Total DVD sales are down by about 4 percent for the year, contributing to a creeping dread in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: Total DVD sales are down by about 4 percent for the year, contributing to a creeping dread in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Conventional wisdom holds that Hollywood’s fortunes go up when the economy goes down. People still crave entertainment, particularly of the escapist variety, and movies remain within the budgets of most people.

articles.headline: Fields of Grain and Losses
articles.snippet: Hard times are back on the American farmstead, as the price paid for crops is dropping much faster than the cost of growing them.
articles.abstract: Hard times are back on the American farmstead, as the price paid for crops is dropping much faster than the cost of growing them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTERS, Okla.  The farmers said it would not last, and they were right.

articles.headline: Looking to Washington Amid Turmoil, So Far in Vain
articles.snippet: With the stock market plunging and the credit market freezing, cries are being heard for quick government intervention.
articles.abstract: With the stock market plunging and the credit market freezing, cries are being heard for quick government intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Americans await the arrival of a new administration in Washington, investors are worrying whether the financial system is again in the danger zone.

articles.headline: Angelina Jolie’s Carefully Orchestrated Image
articles.snippet: The actress pushed for favorable coverage while negotiating magazine rights to pictures of her new twins.
articles.abstract: The actress pushed for favorable coverage while negotiating magazine rights to pictures of her new twins.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt negotiated with People and other celebrity magazines this summer for photos of their newborn twins and an interview, the stars were seeking more than the estimated $14 million they received from the deal. They also wanted a hefty slice of journalistic input  a promise that the winning magazine’s coverage would be positive, not merely in that instance but into the future.

articles.headline: Citigroup Tries to Stop the Drop in Its Share Price
articles.snippet: The greatest banking turmoil is setting in around Citigroup, which has lost half its value in four days.
articles.abstract: The greatest banking turmoil is setting in around Citigroup, which has lost half its value in four days.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, the nation’s largest banks have struggled to regain investors’ trust. In the center of the vortex is Citigroup, whose precipitous stock-market plunge accelerated on Thursday, sending shock waves through the financial world.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story
